thread.title: Missed chances cost Poudre in upset bid of Horizon
thread.title_full: Missed chances cost Poudre in upset bid of Horizon

title: Missed chances cost Poudre in upset bid of Horizon
text:
Missed chances cost Poudre in upset bid of Horizon Kevin Lytle , kevinlytle@coloradoan.com 9:30 p.m. MDT October 22, 2015 Buy Photo Rain falls on French Field as Jason Wooldridge of Poudre High School lines up before a play during a game against Horizon Thursday, October 22, 2015. Austin Humphreys/The Coloradoan Fullscreen Buy Photo Poudre High School quarterback James Campbell is taken down by Horizon defense during a game at French Field Thursday, October 22, 2015. Austin Humphreys/The Coloradoan Fullscreen Buy Photo Jason Wooldridge of Poudre High School weaves through Horizon defense during a game at French Field Thursday, October 22, 2015. Austin Humphreys/The Coloradoan Fullscreen Buy Photo Poudre High School football coach Marty McVicker talks to his team during a time out in a game against Horizon at French Field Thursday, October 22, 2015. Austin Humphreys/The Coloradoan Fullscreen Buy Photo Joseph Erickson of Poudre High School makes the tackle on Leo Rodriguez of Horizon during a game at French Field Thursday, October 22, 2015. Austin Humphreys/The Coloradoan Fullscreen Buy Photo Tyler Lawrence and Dillon Foster of Poudre High School celebrate after a touchdown in a game against Horizon at French Field Thursday, October 22, 2015. Austin Humphreys/The Coloradoan Fullscreen Buy Photo Jacob Lippert of Poudre High School reacts to a 20-13 loss to Horizon at French Field Thursday, October 22, 2015. Austin Humphreys/The Coloradoan Fullscreen Buy Photo Water droplets collect on the helmet of a Poudre High School football player during a game at French Field against Horizon Thursday, October 22, 2015. Austin Humphreys/The Coloradoan Fullscreen Buy Photo Rain pours onto the field as Poudre High School takes on Horizon during a game at French Field Thursday, October 22, 2015. Austin Humphreys/The Coloradoan Fullscreen Buy Photo Jason Wooldridge of Poudre High School weaves through Horizon defense during a game at French Field Thursday, October 22, 2015. Austin Humphreys/The Coloradoan Fullscreen Buy Photo Jack Walbye of Poudre High School stands in the middle of French Field as the Horizon High School football team celebrates a 20-13 win over the Impalas Thursday, October 22, 2015. Austin Humphreys/The Coloradoan Fullscreen Buy Photo Dillon Foster of Poudre High School weaves through Horizon defense during a game at French Field Thursday, October 22, 2015. Austin Humphreys/The Coloradoan Fullscreen Buy Photo Poudre High School quarterback James Campbell sends the ball deep down the field during a game at French Field Thursday, October 22, 2015. Austin Humphreys/The Coloradoan Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Jason Wooldridge of Poudre High School weaves through Horizon defense during a game at French Field Thursday. Horizon won 20-13. (Photo: Austin Humphreys/The Coloradoan) 2 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
This is the tale of a team thisclose . 
This is a team that's had enough "what ifs?" to cause insomnia. 
The Poudre High School football team is on the edge of the playoff bubble and needed a big win to snap a losing streak. 
Once again the Impalas were right there with a chance to win Thursday night, but once again they fell short. 
This one was a 20-13 loss to Horizon on a frigid, rainy night at French Field that clinches the Front Range League title for the Hawks and sends Poudre to its fifth loss in a row. 
"We've had so many times where we've made little mistakes," coach Marty McVicker said. "We're just that close to beating one of these teams. A win against this team in the (wild card) points would make a big difference." 
Poudre (3-5, 1-5 FRL) entered the week 31st in wild card points, with 32 teams making the Class 5A playoffs. 
Included in those losses five-straight losses is a defeat to Fairview where the would-be game-winning touchdown was stopped an inch short. There's also a last-second field goal loss to Fossil Ridge. 
Thursday's narrow defeat is a story of more missed chances. 
Horizon (7-1, 6-0 FRL) is the best defensive team in 5A, allowing nine points a game. The Hawks went up 13-0 in the first quarter, but Poudre responded. 
A 40-yard strike from James Campbell to Zach Leal made it 13-7. 
Not long after the Impalas recovered a fumble. On the first play from Horizon's 25, Campbell hit Jason Wooldridge over the middle. 
Right before he crossed the goal line for the go-ahead score, he fumbled and the Hawks recovered. 
In the second quarter Poudre also had a 27-yard screen from Campbell to Dillon Foster go for a touchdown, but it was called back on a holding penalty. 
Austin Davis hit a 47-yard field goal late in the fourth to cut Horizon's lead to seven, then executed a perfect onside kick that Poudre recovered. 
But the Impalas final true chance at a comeback ended on the next play when Campbell was intercepted. 
Poudre's final regular season game is at 7 p.m. Oct. 30 at Mountain Range. The Impalas almost surely will need a win to have a chance of making the playoffs. 
"They're discouraged after winning three, then losing five in a row," McVicker said. "It's a tough lesson. We've just got to keep working." 
Follow sports reporter Kevin Lytle at twitter.com/Kevin_Lytle and at facebook.com/KevinSLytle. 
Horizon 20, Poudre 13
